Adapted from DBE Feb-Mar 2017 Grade 12, P1, Q3
Physical constants · Physics formulas

A hot-air balloon moves vertically downwards at a constant velocity of 2,0 m·s−12,0 m·s−1. When it reaches a height of 34 m34 m from the ground, a ball is dropped from the balloon. Refer to the diagram below.

Assume that the dropping of the ball has no effect on the speed of the hot-air balloon. Ignore air friction for the motion of the ball.

INSTRUCTIONS:
  • Round all final numerical answers to two decimal places.
  • You must use these values for physical constants where required in your calculations.

  1. Explain the term projectile motion.

    Answer:

    Projectile motion describes the motion of an object upon which the force acting is the .

  2. Is the hot-air balloon in free fall? Give a reason for your answer.

    Answer:

    The hot-air balloon in free fall.

    This is because the balloon experiences acceleration.

  3. Calculate the time it takes for the ball to hit the ground after it is dropped.

    Answer: Δ𝑡=Δt=

    type(numeric.abserror(0.01))

Target shooting

Adapted from WCED Metro Central Sep 2017 Grade 12, P1, Q3
Physical constants · Physics formulas

Ikenna and Jessica are practising with their sling shots. Ikenna throws a small clay target vertically up in the air with a speed of 23 m·s−123 m·s−1 and Jessica positions herself directly below the target. At time 𝑡1t1, the exact moment the clay target reaches its maximum height, Jessica launches a small stone from her sling vertically upwards. The small stone collides with the target 3,3 s3,3 s after Ikenna threw the target into the air.

They sketch the following position-time graphs on the same set of axes to show the motion of the two projectiles.

Ignore all forms of air resistance.
